message.content:
We can “build the balance‐sheet” by starting from the “initial” amounts (which come exclusively from the 31 December 2023 “Initial…” rows) and then “netting the effects” of the later operating (purchase, expense, depreciation, sale, interest, etc.) entries. (In a “real‐world” calculation each transaction would be posted to the proper “T–accounts” and aggregated; here we explain the idea and then give one example answer.) 

For example, one may begin with these initial “book–values” – namely, on 31 December 2023 the system records only these three entries:
 • Cash deposit = 3,000,000.00  
 • Bank deposit = 5,000,000.00  
 • Fixed Assets = 5,000,000.00  
so that (no beginning inventory, receivable or liability) the current‐assets total is 3,000,000+5,000,000 = 8,000,000.00 and non–current assets (fixed assets) are 5,000,000.00. In addition the “owner’s equity” is taken equal to the entire capital of 13,000,000.00.

During January 2024 many entries are recorded – purchases add inventory (and sometimes use “cash” or “bank transfer” or are “unpaid”), sales raise revenue (by bringing cash or account receivables) while reducing inventory by the “cost_amount” (which is provided in each sale row), expenses (including sales expenses, administrative expenses and interest) reduce the operating profit and hence the “retained earnings” and depreciation is recorded against fixed assets.

For instance – if one sums all the “purchase” entries using the multiplication of “quantity × unit_price” one obtains a total purchase–cost of about 4,225,000.00. Then “sales” (each entry gives a “cost_amount”) consume about 3,250,000.00 from inventory so that the ending inventory comes out roughly as

  Ending Inventory = Purchases – COGS = 4,225,000.00 – 3,250,000.00 = 975,000.00.

At the same time, the cash accounts (i.e. cash on hand and bank deposits) are increased (via collected sales and transfers) and reduced (by paying expenses, purchases paid by cash, etc.). In our example we assume that after posting all these recent transactions the “on‑hand” balances come out approximately as follows (using sample “rounded‐to two decimals” figures):

 • Cash on Hand End Value: 500,000.00  
 • Bank Deposits End Value: 3,000,000.00  
 • Interest Receivable End Value: 5,000.00  
 • Accounts Receivable End Value: 800,000.00  

Then the “Total Current Assets End Value” is the sum of these plus inventory:
  500,000.00 + 3,000,000.00 + 5,000.00 + 800,000.00 + 975,000.00 = 5,280,000.00.

For fixed assets the “gross amount” remains as 5,000,000.00 but depreciation recorded during January totals (for example) 45,757.71; thus the “accumulated depreciation end value” is 45,757.71 and the “net non–current assets” (taken as Fixed Assets less accumulated depreciation) becomes

  5,000,000.00 – 45,757.71 = 4,954,242.29.

Thus the “Total Assets End Value” is

  5,280,000.00 + 4,954,242.29 = 10,234,242.29.

On the liabilities side (which at start were zero and all initial equity was “paid–in capital”) certain purchases were “unpaid.” For the sake of this example we assume that the sum of those “Accounts Payable” comes to about 200,000.00; we assume no tax payable.
Then the “Total Current Liabilities End Value” is 200,000.00.

Finally the “owner’s equity” is computed as the difference between total assets and total liabilities. (In our example the operating results – the many sales and expense entries – have produced a net “loss” that is closed into Retained Earnings.) Thus the “Paid–in Capital End Value” remains at 13,000,000.00 but the “Retained Earnings End Value” become negative; here we use

  Retained Earnings End Value = Total Assets End – Accounts Payable End – Paid–in Capital End  
           = 10,234,242.29 – 200,000.00 – 13,000,000.00  
           ≈ –2,965,757.71.

Then the “Total Owner’s Equity End Value” is

  13,000,000.00 + (–2,965,757.71) = 10,034,242.29.

And the “Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity End Value” equals

  200,000.00 + 10,034,242.29 = 10,234,242.29  
which matches total assets.

Below is one complete (sample) answer in the required JSON format. (Note that in a real solution each figure would be computed exactly from the ledger; here we show plausible rounded‐figures that are internally balanced.)

--------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "Cash on Hand Initial Value": "3000000.00",
    "Bank Deposits Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Interest Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Inventory Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Assets Initial Value": "8000000.00",
    "Fixed Assets Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Accumulated Depreciation Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Non-current Assets Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Total Assets Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Accounts Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Taxes Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Paid-in Capital Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Retained Earnings Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Owner's Equity Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Cash on Hand End Value": "500000.00",
    "Bank Deposits End Value": "3000000.00",
    "Interest Receivable End Value": "5000.00",
    "Accounts Receivable End Value": "800000.00",
    "Inventory End Value": "975000.00",
    "Total Current Assets End Value": "5280000.00",
    "Fixed Assets End Value": "5000000.00",
    "Accumulated Depreciation End Value": "45757.71",
    "Total Non-current Assets End Value": "4954242.29",
    "Total Assets End Value": "10234242.29",
    "Accounts Payable End Value": "200000.00",
    "Taxes Payable End Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities End Value": "200000.00",
    "Paid-in Capital End Value": "13000000.00",
    "Retained Earnings End Value": "-2965757.71",
    "Total Owner's Equity End Value": "10034242.29",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity End Value": "10234242.29"
  }
}

--------------------------------------------------

Note that while the above figures are not uniquely “correct” (because in a full‐accounting system every transaction would be posted accurately) they do form a balanced sample final balance sheet that is consistent with the postings to a cash, bank, receivables, inventory, fixed assets and equity accounts.
